'South Ossetia' ( or Oxford English Dictionary, 2nd ed. )
or 'Tskhinvali Region' 'South Ossetia' (, Xussar Iryston; ,
Samxreti Oseti; , Yuzhnaya Osetiya) 'Tskhinvali Region' (, Tsxinvalis
regioni; , Tskhinvalskiy region) is a disputed region and partly
recognized state in the South Caucasus, located in the territory of the South
Ossetian Autonomous Oblast within the former Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic
of the USSR. USSR Atlas - in Russian, Moscow 1984

South Ossetians declared independence from Georgia in 1990, calling themselves
the 'Republic of South Ossetia'. The Georgian government responded by abolishing
South Ossetia's autonomy and trying to retake the region by force. http://u-
npan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/UNTC/UNPAN019224.pdf This
led to the 1991â1992 South Ossetia War. Georgian fighting against
those controlling South Ossetia occurred on two other occasions, in 2004 and
2008. The latter conflict led to the
RussiaâGeorgia war, during which Ossetian and Russian forces gained full de
facto control of the territory of the former South Ossetian Autonomous Oblast.

In the wake of the 2008 South Ossetia War, Russia, Nicaragua, Venezuela, Nauru,
and Tuvalu recognized South Ossetia's independence. [-
http://eng.kremlin.ru/speeches/2008/08/26/1543_type82912_205752.shtml President
of Russia] Georgia does not recognize the existence
of South Ossetia as a political entity, including most of the area in its Shida
Kartli region. Georgia considers South Ossetia to be occupied by the Russian
army. [http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=19330 Abkhazia, S.Ossetia
Formally Declared Occupied Territory.] Civil Georgia. 28 August 2008.
